> Let's assume that the problem here is this: JUnit 3, by 
> requiring te=
st 
> cases to all be in memory before any running happens, could be used 
=
> fairly memory effectively, but only if:
> 
> 1) All large TestCase fields=
 were only initialized in setUp
> 2) All large TestCase fields were set bac=
k to null in tearDown
> 
> Otherwise, no test cases or fields could be garb=
age collected, and 
> memory usage climbs steadily up as tests are executed=
.

  I had an issue w/ JUnit running out of memory just before xmas. At
fir=
st I was baffled as running the tests individually went fine but
running a =
lot (hundreds) of tests caused JUnit to run out of memory (the
classes unde=
r test used jaxb to read a lot of xml). After digging I
found that I had mi=
sunderstood how JUnit works. I thought that after a
test is run, there is n=
o more use for that test object so the reference
to it is discarded. This i=
s not so, as I found reading the FAQ entry
"When are tests garbage collecte=
d?": 

http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/faq/faq.htm#tests_18

  So, I made =
tearDown set reference to anything instantiated in setUp to
null and the pr=
oblem was gone. 




       -Antti-
